content.webTitle: The Summer Isles by Philip Marsden review – a voyage of the imagination

fields.headline: The Summer Isles by Philip Marsden review – a voyage of the imagination
fields.bodyText: Travel writer Philip Marsden had never skippered a boat anywhere he couldn’t reach by lunchtime. Yet he decided to sail single-handed up the west coast of Ireland and the Inner Hebrides to the Summer Isles in northern Scotland. As Marsden set out in early spring, he asked himself: “What, in God’s name, have I taken on?” When he was younger he often stayed with his aunt Bridget and her husband Francis in their cottage in north-west Scotland, on the banks of the upper Oykel “in the wilds of Sutherland”. He used to go walking with Bridget: “we developed a fascination for the strange peaks that rise from the moors of Coigach and Assynt – Cùl Mòr, Cùl Beag, Canisp, Suilen, Quinag.” It was on one of these walks, looking west over the sea in the late afternoon sun, that he first saw the Summer Isles, lying like “glyphs and ciphers” tooled into a “sheet of beaten silver”. He later read that the pioneering ecologist and naturalist Frank Fraser Darling had lived on one of the islands, Tanera Mòr, in the 1930s. He and Bridget decided to visit the islands, but before they could do so, she was killed in a climbing accident on Ben More Assynt. Marsden vowed that one day he would visit the Summer Isles, but as the years passed they came to symbolise the longing for a place that exists more in the imagination than in reality. His book is therefore both a travelogue and an exploration of mythical islands, those “places just beyond our reach, places that aren’t really there at all”. According to Marsden, “the ability to believe in places that are invisible, to build stories around them and inhabit them, remains the defining attribute of our species”. Nowhere is richer in imaginary places than the western seas, where the fickle currents, fractured coastline and constantly changing weather made crossings dangerous and deepened the mystery around those islands lost in the mist or just over the horizon. There are countless mythical islands in these waters, from Tír na nÓg (land of the young), Avalon, Hinba and the Green Island, to Elysium. Marsden’s own home in Cornwall was once owned by a family who lost all their money in the 16th century “looking for an island called Hy-Brasil”. Marsden’s odyssey in his wooden boat, Tsambika, takes him up the western fringe of the archipelago – “Europe’s dreaming frontier” – through a rich territory of real and imagined places. There are memorable historical anecdotes and encounters with local people on the islands he visits, such as the crofter and poet John Purser on Skye, whose words appear on the beams of Edinburgh’s Library of Scottish Poetry: “A nation is forged in the hearth of poetry.” There is real danger, too, as Marsden faces violent storms and even a powerful whirlpool. But as he says, “Looking for imaginary places isn’t meant to be easy.” He writes beautifully, and transforms what could easily have been a conventional travel book into something far more evocative and personal: “a sea journey is a passage of the soul”. The harsh coastal landscapes and shifting moods of the sea are vividly described. But what is so memorable and indeed magical is the way he interweaves the imaginary and the real. In these islands at the edge of the Atlantic, staring out into “the endless blue of the west”, he finds a rich tradition of myth, poetry and ancient lore that still speaks to us across the gulf of time. • The Summer Isles is published by Granta (£20).
